Robab maestro Daud Khan Sadozai performs at the World Sacred Spirit Festival in Jodhpur on Sunday.— Photo: PTI

With his roots in Afghanistan, robab exponent Daud Khan Sadozai says that the art of Sufi devotional music with such musical instruments is on the decline.

Sadozai picked up the art of playing robab as a child.

“At that time, musicians used to be serious, they worshipped the art. People have lost the power of patience today and now everything comes at a price so it has turned into show business. You need patience for these kind of arts because they are meditative in a way and it takes time to understand,” Sadozai said at the World Sacred Spirit Festival here.

“These days, youngsters want everything immediately like fast food. It is a problem to tune the instruments as it’s so difficult. It has 25 strings,” he saud.

He feels lucky that when he was a student, it was peaceful in Afghanistan and at “that time, all ustads (gurus) used to live in the same neighbourhood so we learnt there.”

Sadozai also studied the sarod, a descendent of the robab, with Ustad Amjad Ali Khan in India.

Amjad Ali Khan’s ancestors are said to have brought the robab from Afghanistan to India and developed the sarod.

Amjad Ali Khan and his sons Amaan and Ayaan mesmerised the audience at the Sacred Spirit Festival with their soulful performance on Saturday.

Folk songs were performed by the band Maati Baani. — IANS

title: Robab exponent says the art is vanishing
